title: What is the nature of all things? - Quora

response.answer_text: There are two types of realities—immaterial and material. Both are real and eternal. Both are required as darkness glorifies the light, and suffering glorifies the well-being. In other words, during night we crave for day, and vice versa; in rainy season we crave for summer; in suffering we crave for well-being. This is true of all pairs of opposites—in small scale and in large scale. People swing between two opposites! This situation is required and it has to be so. The broader our perspective is the more firmly we would say the above. Imagine you are drinking a sweet juice. The more continuous your drinking is more diminishing will be its sweetness you feel. Now try this—take a sip of juice, and eat two or three pieces of snacks or peanut, and again take a sip of juice and alternate the juice-drinking with snacks …you will have the sweetness with each sip. That means opposite situations/feelings should alternate for life to be enjoyable. Now apply this in large scale. Infinity is a fact—we have time, space, energy …. If they remain as they are like infinite oceans, there is no fun, no charm. Energy should be transformed into various forms which brings beauty into universe. Light has meaning only when there is darkness. Consciousness has meaning only when there are things that are not conscious. So there should be spirit and matter. If spirit and matter remains as they are, then too there is no charm. They both should come in contact with each other. This lays the basis for all pairs of opposites. It’s like you try to draw picture of a flower on any surface. After the completion of the painting, flower looks SOFT as its inherent feature is; yet while touching, it is as rough as the medium on which it is sustained. Your work is limited by the limitations of the medium you are using! Similarly, when Atma (spirit) comes in association with matter, it comes into a pair of opposites, which lays the ground for the appearance of a variety of pairs of opposites. Matter provides Atma pleasure which become pain in the end. Thus we have the situation where things come in pairs of opposites (such as pleasure-pain; happiness-sorrow; victory-defeat; day-night; life-death …etc). One follows the other. History also comes in pairs of opposites, as an eternal cycle of two halves—first half is earthly heaven and second half is earthly hell. This can be known from the very name, Duniya, by which this world is now called in many languages. DUNIYA is an interesting name. If you describe second half of a movie as boring, you obviously mean its first half was interesting. Similarly, if the second half of history is named as duniya [negative prefix + niya], it obviously mean first half of history was perfect, characterized by niya. To act with niya, in Arabic, means ‘to act with loyalty and good faith, being led in righteousness’ so naturally as though water flows downward. (Criminal Justice: Nomos XXVII edited by Ronald Pennock, John W. Chapman. page 58). Duniya means phase of history where people act mostly irrationally, as we find today polluting the air, water, and land as though cutting the branch one sits on.

A2A - What is the nature of all things? The nature of realityReality, whatever it is formed of, presents a persistent and consistent environment. Therefore, knowledge is possible. Knowledge of our environment provides information useful to us while we are embedded in our environment. Knowledge about reality, whatever it is formed of, does not necessarily provide useful information outside the framework of that reality. Reality includes an underlying physical perception. We perceive physical objects using our 5 senses. Furthermore, there are things that are intangible. For example: Beauty, Bravery, Brutality, Charity, Courage, Curiosity, Enthusiasm, Envy, Evil, Fear , Generosity, Goodness, Honesty, Honor , Hope, Humility, Jealousy , Kindness, Life, Loyalty, Patience, Sympathy, Talent, Tolerance, Trust, Warmth, Weakness, Wisdom, Amazement, Anger , Anxiety, Despair , Happiness, Hate, Joy , Love, Misery, Pain , Pleasure, Pride, Sadness, Satisfaction, Strength, Artistry, Awe, Belief, Faith, Forgiveness, Imagination, Luck, Mercy, Peace, Poverty, Truth, and Wealth. And though there are many, many more intangible objects, we find that they all are ideas or concepts existing in mankind’s thoughts and may manifest themselves in mankind’s deeds.

You ask what is the nature of all things. Thank you. What a wonderful question. One answer is in Genesis chapters 2 and 3. Another answer is in the Tao Te Ching: Naming is the origin of all particular things. The nature of all things is that each thing is separate from and exclusively not any other thing. Thus, in the world of things, a chair is not the rain, and I am not my coffee cup. This leads to some interesting situations. I cannot be a thing that I have, as I am not my coffee cup. Now, thinking about this, you think with your mind. Since you have a mind, you are not your mind. So, who has the mind that thinks it is you? This brings me back to Genesis 2–3. Our worldly mind separates all existence into separate things, and so it separates God as a separate thing. This is why we cannot see or find God, because “I” look always “out there” to find a God who is separated from “me.” That is the nature of all things. See what happens when you ask questions of deranged old men wandering the high valleys of Oregon?
